results.title: RAAF Newsreel. No. 9. Operation sabre ferry
results.creator_credit: Harry Rayner and Australia. Royal Australian Air Force
results.brief_description: Newsreel items including: 1. No. 3 Squadron and No. 77 Squadron of the RAAF ferry the Sabre Jet from the east coast of Australia to Butterworth in Malaya via Townsville, Darwin, Netherlands New Guinea, Philippines, Borneo, Malaya. 2. Firefighter - RAAF demonstrates capability of new firefighting truck. 3. Addition of the new Air to Air Missile to the Sabre Jet Fighter. Test fired at Woomera.

results.title: Women breakout
results.creator_credit: Erika Addis and Halfway House Collective
results.brief_description: This film was made by the Halfway House Collective in Melbourne and is set in Halfway House a feminist refuge. The film does not so much focus on the circumstances that led them to the Halfway House, rather it shows the house giving them support to take control of and change their lives.

results.title: Ship No. 76
results.brief_description: Shows all stages of the construction of the 18,600 ton oil tanker, B.P. Endeavour, at the Newcastle State Dockyard. The Endeavour was the largest ship built in Australia up to 1967.

results.title: Grampians wonderland
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description:
The Grampians mountain ranges rising from the plains of western Victoria were discovered by Major Mitchell and continue to delight tourists. This program shows the exquisite wildflowers, the animal life, the rugged mountain scenery and the foaming waterfalls which make the Grampians so beautiful and so popular. Winner of an AFI Award: 1959.

The convertable car used in this film is a Triumph TR3A.

results.title: First aid
results.brief_description: A film of historic interest: an official training film produced for the War department in three parts. Part 1: emergency treatment of bleeding wounds, including self-administration. Covers the arterial system, pressure points and application of tournequets. Part 2: emergency treatment of broken bones. Part 3: covers methods of removing the wounded.

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This film shows Dr Raymond Penington’s girls in the late 1930s and brief scenes of other members of the family.

While the film is focused around his three daughters the main theme throughout is the youngest daughter, Jocelyn Penington.

The film is located mainly in two places, the back yard at home and the beach, though there is a brief scene in the snow. It covers a short period as the girls grow up.

While a very personal film, of interest for a general viewer includes fashion of the time which includes all generations.

There is a scene which appears to be a birthday party where games of the time are being played such as statues.

Also seen is an old tricycle and scooter.

The film finishes as it started, with the family at the beach.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Edith Penington and daughter Jocelyn at the beach
00:01:21:00 Jocelyn Penington shuffling on her bottom in the yard at home while her sisters, Margaret on a tricycle and Vivienne on a scooter, play around her
00:05:08:00 the women and girls play with a kitten in the yard
00:05:43:00 Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn Penington running around in swimwear through a sprinkler
00:06:12:00 Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn Penington playing ring a ring a rosy
00:06:39:00 Dr Raymond Penington playing ring a ring a rosy with his daughters
00:08:04:00 the Penington family in the snow
00:09:06:00 girls playing games in the back yard (possibly a birthday party)
00:10:42:00 a puppy and rabbit interacting with each other
00:11:47:00 Penington girls and their grandparents
00:14:50:00 Penington family at the beach

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This film shows the construction site during the expansion of the Eildon Dam.

The film shows many construction vehicles including cranes, trucks and bulldozers.

At the beginning of the film we see a crane has fallen over and attempts to raise it up again. However, the conclusion is not seen.

There is also a scene of the Lake Eildon Tower shown almost complete.

Most of the film shows machines redistributing dirt. A sign in the film indicates that 9,000,000 tons of soil was planned to be moved.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Big Eildon Project sign
00:00:13:00 view of Eildon Lake
00:00:36:00 scene of crane that has fallen down a bank
00:00:42:00 bulldozers
00:01:07:00 sign indicating Spillway Site - Max Depth 300 Feet – rock excavation 9,000,000 tons
00:01:32:00 loading of dirt onto trucks
00:05:04:00 the Eildon Tower under construction
00:05:37:00 night shot of bulldozer

results.title: [Royal District Nursing Service TV Ad]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

This television advertisement is an appeal for donations to the Royal District Nursing Service. Filmed in black and white, the advertisement shows a nurse visiting various patients in the community, including babies, the elderly, disabled and blind. A voiceover describes the valuable contribution the nurses make to the community, with over 300,000 visits per year - enough patients to fill the largest public hospital.

results.title: [Mental Hygiene Authority 1961]
results.brief_description:
This film was made by the Mental Hygiene Authority of Victoria (later the Mental Health Authority), of which psychiatrist Eric Cunningham Dax was the inaugural Chairman. Dax was an advocate for greater community engagement with mental health and the introduction of art and education programs within psychiatric care. During his tenure, he implemented widespread reform of mental health institutions.

This film shows scenes at the Oakleigh Retarded Childrens Centre, the Oakleigh Sheltered Workshop and the Larundel Psychiatric Hospital. In the film, we see developmentally and intellectually disabled children and adults engaged in activities in the centres including learning how to weave using looms and working on items such as shoelaces and hubcaps in workshop environements. We also see patients of the psychiatric hospital working and playing table tennis.

results.title: [District Nursing Appeal]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.
